The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: competition-watchdog-blocks-sainsburys-asda-merger
story: In its final report into the deal, theCompetition and Markets Authorityfound that it would lead to increased prices in stores, online and at petrol stations across the UK.:Sainsburys - Asda merger at risk after competition watchdog warningShoppers and motorists would be ldquoworse offSainsburyrsquos and Walmart-owned Asda were to merge, the CMA said, adding that a tie-up would lead to price rises, reductions in the quality and range of products or a poorer overall retail experience.The watchdog claimed that the deal would have resulted in a ldquosubstantial lessening of competition at both a national and local level for people shopping in supermarkets.Wersquove blocked the Sainsburyrsquos   Asda merger after finding that it would lead to:# Higher prices for groceries and fuel# Less choice and worse quality of products## A poor shopping experienceRead more: https:t.co FrOpssqwS pic lJQtkBbeCmdash Competition  Markets AuthorityApril , Stuart McIntosh, chairman of the CMA inquiry group, said: ldquoItrsquos our responsibility to protect the millions of people who shop at Sainsburyrsquos and Asda every week.ldquoFollowing our in-depth investigation, we have found this deal would lead to increased prices, reduced quality and choice of products, or a poorer shopping experience for all of their UK shoppers.ldquoWe have concluded that there is no effective way of addressing our concerns, other than to block the merger.Sainsburyrsquos boss Mike Coupe said that the decision effectively takes pound billion out of customersrsquo pockets.Prior to Thursdayrsquos decision, Sainsburyrsquos and Walmart-owned Asda had offered to sell up to  stores as part of efforts to address competition concerns, and claimed that shoppers would be deprived of lower prices should it be blocked.The duo had pledged to make a number of post-merger commitments, had the deal been approved. It included investing pound billion a year in lowering prices by the third year of the deal completing, equating to a % cut on everyday items.:Sainsburyrsquos and Asda in talks over poundbn mergerMr Coupe said on Thursday: ldquoThe specic reason for wanting to merge was to lower prices for customers. The CMArsquos conclusion that we would increase prices post-merger ignores the dynamic and highly competitive nature of the UK grocery market. The CMA is today effectively taking pound billion out of customersrsquo pockets.Sainsburyrsquos, Walmart and Asda have now mutually agreed to terminate the transaction.A merger between the duo, the UKrsquos number two and three supermarkets, would have created a supermarket titan bigger than Tesco with revenues of pound billion and a network of , Sainsburyrsquos, Asda and Argos stores.But fears had been expressed that suppliers could get squeezed as a result, with the tie-up giving the merged entity increased buying power.The move to reject the tie-up marks the first major decision the CMA has made since the appointment of former Tory MP Andrew Tyrie as chairman.Best known for his role as head of the influential Treasury Select Committee, Mr Tyrie gained a reputation as an effective inquisitor of corporate figures.It remains unclear where the duo go from here, but it is understood that Walmart will continue to look to sell Asda to another buyer.Walmart chief executive Judith McKenna said: ldquoWhile wersquore disappointed by the CMArsquos final report and conclusions, our focus now is continuing to position Asda as a strong UK retailer delivering for customers. Walmart will ensure Asda has the resources it needs to achieve that.Roger Burnley, the Asda boss, said that he is ldquodisappointed in the CMArsquos decision.

title: highland-scots-face-biggest-mortgage-arrears
story: People living in Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch have been found to have the highest level of mortgage arrears in Scotland, while also facing increased costs for utilities.The influx of people buying second properties - either to rent or as holiday homes - has been partly blamed for pushing up the cost of buying a house and pricing locals out of the market.A study by national debt charity StepChange found that almost one in three householders was behind on their mortgage payments, with the average being a colossal pound,.Meanwhile, the same report also showed that the Highlands and Islands has the highest electricity bill arrears out of the eight Scottish regions with pound,, and the second highest for gas debt at pound.:, Scots kids live in households on a financial clf edgeOverall, the average debt held by people in the Highlands and Islands as a region was pound, compared to a Scottish norm of pound,, the Scotland in the Red survey found.StepChange believes that almost three quarters of a million in Scotland are at risk of problematic debts, or already face money troubles.The charity said that mortgage and other arrears a primary symptom of poverty along with poor housing conditions, welfare cuts, ill-health and insecure work. It found a an increase in the numer of people borrowing, and helped more clients with personal loans.Many are attracted to Lochaber for its stunning viewsKate Forbes, MSP for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch, said the figures were "extremely worrying" and driven by higher utility costs and more economic fragility.She added: "Behind every figure is a family struggling to make ends meet and feeling the weight of debt on their shoulders.ldquoA lot of poverty in the Highlands goes unseen and unchecked, so reports like this are important for bringing facts into the light. Charities, like Christians Against Poverty and Step Change can help families deal with debt and I would strongly encourage anybody with the burden of debt to get in touch with them.ldquoThere are obviously particular pressures in my constituency, which means that the average mortgage debt is signicantly higher than the Highland average."The gap between average income and average house prices is wider than in many other parts of Scotland."Kate Forbes MSPMs Forbes said that the Scottish Government was trying to mitigate the worst of the issues, especially the crisis in housing.The MSP said: "There will be additional reasons for these figures, not least the much lower number of properties to let or to rent, leaving people with little choice but to buy.ldquoI think the solutions to this are many and ied. Whilst the Government has a programme of work that means over , new homes have been built across Scotland since the SNP came to power, there remains a challenge with second homes in the Highlands absorbing additional housing and driving up prices.:Scottish household savings have collapsed under Tory GovernmentldquoWe also need to make sure it is lsquomixed tenurersquo and there are dferent types of affordability ndash properties to rent, shared equity schemes and self-build funds."These figures are, of course, indicative of a lack of construction over ten years ago and I would hope that with a renewed focus on accessible, affordable housing and increased supply, we start to see a reduction in these unacceptable high levels of debt.StepChange helped more than , people across Scotland last year, and said that the biggest worry mist had was with Council Tax arrears.The number of people seeking help with debt is increasingAlmost , people had trouble paying their local authority bills, with an average backlog of pound,.Meanwhile, nearly  in  people who approached the charity were behind on their electricity bill, a  per cent jump on . They owed an average of pound, a % increase in just one year.:Nearly half a million food bank parcels given out in  months, figures show#More Scots are being pushed into debt because of reductions in income or benefits, the charity said, with a quarter of the people it helped saying that a reduction social security payments was the reason the were in the red - an increase of % in just one year.Sharon Bell, Head of StepChange Debt Charity Scotland said: ldquoThe vast majority of StepChange clients are in problem debt due to circumstances they could not have prevented or planned for such as unemployment, ill-health or reductions in income."I am increasingly alarmed by the increases in the proportion of our clients who are struggling with household bills, particularly Council Tax. Our research shows that our clients in Scotland are signicantly more likely to have Council Tax arrears compared to where in the UK.ldquoWe are seeing a record level of demand for help with problem debt with over a third of our clients having an additional vulnerability, such as illness. We need more signposting to free debt advice, as the earlier someone gets debt advice the greater their options may be and the less harm they could experience.

title: new-yes-group-to-try-friendly-chats-instead-of-shouty-men
story: Voices for Scotland, a spin-off of the cross-party Scottish Independence Convention, hopes to sway voters with the art of conversation, not berate them.It plans to offer independence campaigners resources to use on the doorstep, hold town hall meetings, and run a website to help inform the debate.It will be chaired by former SNP MSP Dave Thompson whose quick thinking in the  election led to the recount of the Highlands  Islands list ballot that gave the SNP its one-seat victory.Set up in , the Scottish Independence Convention includes the Greens, SNP, Scottish Socialists, Radical Independence, and other Yes groups.Convention chair Elaine C Smith said Brexit had shown what can happen to a country after a narrow referendum result, and she wanted a ldquobig majority for independence, not a % win.She said: ldquoI know a lot of people out there will say, lsquoThat will dorsquo, but for me and many many others, it has to be that we take a big majority of the country with us.ldquoIn order to do that, we have to change our discourse. We have to look at how we speak to the rest of Scotland.ldquoOne of the most disappointing things for me and many others is that the discourse seemed to become very shouty. There was a lot of shouty men shouting at each other from either side of the barricades.ldquoWe need something better than that.The actress added: ldquoI want to hear from the people who voted No and why they voted No.ldquoWhat is needed is a safe space where people feel they will be listened to, not shouted down, and give their very legitimate reasons for voting No or not being convinced by the arguments.ldquoThatrsquos what Voices for Scotland aims to be - that safe space.ldquoTo allow people with dferent opinions to come forward and not be answered with, lsquoHerersquos a tract you can readrsquo, but we answer them in a respectful and uplting way, and not tell anyone on the other side that they were unpatriotic. The people I know who voted No love Scotland.Mr Thompson said: ldquoOur aim is to get independence support up to %. Wersquoll do that as quickly as we possibly can. Thatrsquos the target. But whatever it is by the time the referendum is called, wersquoll be working really hard to raise the percentage up to the % level, because we need to get big support for independence so that it is absolutely clear the people of Scotland support independence for Scotland.Voices for Scotland board member Tony McCandless said he wanted the group to be ldquoan open invitation to people outside the Yes movement.Also at the grouprsquos launch at the Scottish Storytelling Centre, veteran journalist Ruth Wishart said older voters had been ldquocynically manipulated by scaremongering over their finances in .She said Scotland could be dragged into post-Brexit isolation and chaos in pursuit of a ldquoracially infused fantastical golden age which never existed or ldquoslough off the mantle of subservience.Backed a by a recent pound, crowdfunding campaign, the group commissioned academic research which found young women emerging as a key demographic in the Yes campaign.It found females aged  to  felt particularly aggrieved at the loss of le opportunity represented by Brexit.However the elderly remained highly risk averse as they often had no other source of income than their pensions, and were deeply concerned about anything that threatened them.Ms Smith said the timing of the launch, the day after Nicola Sturgeon announced a push on a second referendum, was coincidental.She admitted there was a ldquoline of communication, but added the group was ldquocertainly not a front for the SNP.

title: theresa-may-urged-to-call-in-scotland-yard-to-find-out-who-leaked-sensitive-nsc-information
story: The demand for a criminal investigation into how an unprecedented breach of security happened was made by Sir Michael Fallon, the former Defence Secretary, and came as senior Cabinet minister after senior Cabinet minister stepped forward to insist they were not the leaker.The NSC is a private forum where high-ranking ministers and senior officials from MI, MI and GCHQ can discuss frankly highly sensitive information.Senior ministerial sources confirmed Sir Mark Sedwill, the Cabinet Secretary and National Security Advisor, had begun a top-level Whitehall probe, enraged about the leak of the Governmentrsquos apparent decision to allow the Chinese firm Huawei to supply equipment for the UKrsquos G mobile phone networks.However, Sir Michael insisted an internal investigation was not enough given the gravity of the security breach.ldquoThis is too serious a matter for that, he declared. ldquoIt does require Scotland Yard to be called in and for the police to be involved. I hope Downing St wake up to that, insisted the Scot.He pointed out howa minister was found to have been responsible, they could face prosecution under the Official Secrets Act.ldquoItrsquos extraordinary to think a minister can leak details of the NSC and then think they can get away with it. Thatrsquos why a police inquiry now is so important, added Sir Michael.Downing St declined to comment on the leak but the Prime Ministerrsquos spokesman reflected her anger by saying: "The Prime Minister is clear: the protection of information on matters of national security is of the highest importance.It was suggested a raft of senior ministers present at this weekrsquos NSC had raised security concerns about giving the G contract to Huawei, which operates under the governance of a Communist regime.Among these were Jeremy Hunt, the Foreign Secretary, Sajid Javid, the Home Secretary, and Gavin Williamson, the Defence Secretary all said to harbour ambitions to succeed Mrs May when she leaves Downing St.One Whitehall insider claimed the leak was "evidently briefed to make a leadership candidate look tough on China".But, one by one, ministers came forward to decry the security breach and insist they were not to blame.Mr Hunt, speaking at a press gallery lunch at Westminster, described it as ldquoutterly appalling. When asked directlyhe or any of his staff had leaked the NSC information, the Foreign Secretary replied firmly: ldquoNo.Mr Javid said it was "completely unacceptable" for any Government minister to "share sensitive information that cannot be out in the public domain" andit happened, it should "absolutely be looked at".Mr Williamson made clear: ldquoNeither I nor any of my team have ulged information from the National Security Council."Such was the concern about the leak that Labour was successfully granted an Urgent Question in the Commons.Jo Platt, the Shadow Cabinet Office Minister, who called for a leak inquiry, saidit was found a minister had been responsible, then they were not fit to be in Cabinet or to become prime minister."Indeed,the leak was for an advantage in a Tory leadership race that would be truly shocking. Critical issues of national security should be handled with utmost care, not used as political ammunition in a Tory Party civil war, insisted the Greater Manchester MP.The SNPrsquos Martin Docherty-Hughes, who sits on the Commons Defence Committee, also denounced what he described as a ldquoshocking breach of protocol at the very highest levels.The West Dunbartonshire MP added: ldquoIt is unacceptable that the NSC has been shamefully turned into a tool for Tory leadership contenders.ldquoA full and thorough inquiry must get to the bottom of this, andneeded, a criminal inquiry, so those found to be responsible are properly held to account."

title: scottish-independence-poll-one-in-five-scots-back-nicola-sturgeons-indyref2-plan
story: In a blow to the FirstMinisterrsquos plan for a fresh vote by , only one in five said they wanted to revisit theNo result of  within two years.But the Survation survey for the Scotland in Union group also included far more positive news for the First Minister.It found thatthere was a general election tomorrow, the SNP would win almost as much of the vote as Labour and the Tories combined, and pick up  of Scotlandrsquos  seats.The poll also found  per cent of people want Scotland to stay in the UK, and only % want out of the Union, although the question was couched in terms of Leave and Remain, rather than the more familiar Yes or No to independence.:Nicola Sturgeon jokes she would personally dingy President Donald TrumpMs Sturgeon announced on Wednesday she intended to introduce a framework bill for a fresh referendum at Holyrood, and would ask MSPs to pass it be the end of the year.She said it would allow Scotland to protect its interestsBrexit took place, but admitted it would require a transfer of power from Westminster, a so-called Section  order, before a legally watertight referendum could take place.With the UK Government refusing to grant a Section  order, the Tories dubbed it a ldquobill to nowhere.Theresa Mayrsquos deputy David Lidington yesterday restated the Governmentrsquos opposition at a cyber security conference in Glasgow.The Cabinet Office Minister said: ldquoWe donrsquot see any evidence there is a demand from the people of Scotland for a revisit of the decision they took in . That referendum was something the First Minister and her colleagues said at the time would settle matters for a generation. We donrsquot see that a Section  Order is called for.ldquoI donrsquot see that is going to help put right Scottish schools and Scottish hospitals.Ms Sturgeonrsquos plan was also savaged by former SNP justice secretary Kenny MacAskill, who said anyone who believed it would make Indyref happen soon was ldquodelusional.In an article for the Scotsman, Mr MacAskill said the planrsquos purpose was appeasing SNP activists at this weekendrsquos party conference, who are impatient for action on independence.He wrote: ldquoHolding another referendumrsquos problematic and those expecting an immediate poll delusional. The talk of a poll before  initially sounds positive but itrsquos heavily caveated and restricted by other factors.ldquoWill the UK have resolved its EU position by then  If that has been settled, can a poll even be carried out in time  But it allows [the FM] to reassure the party this weekend that shersquos undaunted and the light undimmed.Ms Sturgeon also announced a Citizensrsquo Assembly to consider Scotlandrsquos future this week.:Scottish independence: How European media reacted to Nicola Sturgeons indyref updateHer Brexit Secretary Michael Russell told MSPs he hoped to publish details of the Assembly and the bill by the end of May.Although Ms Sturgeon said the reason for the referendum was to offer Scots a way out of Brexit, Finance Secretary Derek Mackay refused to rule out pushing ahead with it evenBrexit was cancelled.Asked on Radio Scotlandthe SNP would take the referendum off the tableitsBrexit-based mandate no longer existed, he said: ldquoWhat wersquore saying is Scotland should have the right to choose. We should keep our options open.Ms Sturgeonrsquos official spokesman also refused to discuss the Governmentrsquos plansBrexit was cancelled, saying it was premature to do so, despite the new bill in case Brexit isnrsquot cancelled.The Survation online poll, which surveyed  Scottish adults between April  to , found % of people thought there should ldquonever be another Scottish independence referendum ndash the most popular answer.Another % thought there should be one at some stage but not for at least  years, % said it should be held in five to  years, % in two to five years, and % undecided.Ms Sturgeonrsquos timescale on within two years was supported by % of respondents.Asked how they would vote in a referendum with the question ldquoshould Scotland remain in the United Kingdom or leave the United Kingdom  % said Remain and % Leave.The poll also found % of respondents thought leavingthe UK would be worse forScotlandrsquos economy than Brexit would, while % thought it would be better than Brexit.A further % said it would be no better or worse and % said they did not know.Asked their top three priorities, % said the NHS, % said the cost of living, % the economy, % education, and % constitutional affairs and independence.:UK wont allow second Scottish independence referendum - David LidingtonAsked how they would vote in a Westminster election tomorrow, the SNP was backed by %, Labour %, the Tories %, and the LibDems %.The Electoral Calculus website said the numbers would translate into MPs for the SNP , the LibDems four , the Tories threeand Labour one .Former Labour MP Pamela Nash, the chief executive of Scotland in Union, said:ldquoThis bombshell poll proves Nicola Sturgeon is refusing to listen to the people of Scotland.ldquoIn a hammer blow for the SNP, only one-fth of voters want a isive second independence referendum within two years, and over half say there shouldnrsquot be one for at least a decade.ldquoItrsquos no surprise that support for leaving the UK has fallen to below %, with many former Yes voters changing their minds.ldquoThey have seen how dficult the Brexit process has been and know we are stronger together.ldquoThe people of Scotland want Nicola Sturgeon to get back to her day job and focus on fixing our hospitals, schools and the economy, and to drop her obsession with breaking up the UK.Depute SNP leader Keith Brown said his partyrsquos -point poll lead over the Tories was the largest since , and called it a ldquospectacular boomerang for Scotland in Union.He said: ldquoThis poll has backfired in spectacular style for Scotland in Union, who are clearly running scared of giving people in Scotland the choice over their future. The SNP meets for our spring conference with the wind in our sails, while the Unionist parties continue to languish in the political doldrums.ldquoWersquore -points clear of the Tories as we stand up for Scotland against the damage that their Brexit plans will inflict on jobs and our NHS. Theyrsquove slumped into a dismal third place behind a beleaguered Labour party.ldquoThis poll shows that almost two thirds of people back another referendum and that a majority think Scotland would be better off or no worse off with independence. Thatrsquos a great vote of confidence in the benefits of taking our future into our own hands.ldquoDespite their best efforts in employing a skewed question on support for independence conducted before the First Ministerrsquos announcement this week, Scotland in Union have done us a huge favour.He said this weekendrsquos conference would be a campaign event for the EU elections on May .He said: ldquoThis conference will put us on campaign footing, with a vote for the SNP a vote to make clear that Scotland says no to Brexit.ldquoWith the full powers of independence we can do so much more ndash and conference will debate the economic foundations of an independent Scotland as we build for tomorrow.ldquoScotlandrsquos future lies in Europe ndash and people in Scotland should be given a choice between independence and Brexit.Conservative MSP Maurice Golden said: ldquoNo matter what the SNP says, support for independence simply hasnrsquot risen since the  vote.ldquoThatrsquos all the evidence Nicola Sturgeon should need to take this threat off the table.ldquoBut instead she ploughs on, ensuring Scotland is subjected to yet more ision and uncertainty.ldquoA responsible Scottish Government should be seeking to bring the country together, not drive another wedge through it.

title: a-smiley-emoji-makes-young-people-happier-at-work
story: However think twice before you wink with an emoticon, or use such shorthands to soften bad news and the older you are, and the higher you get, the less respect social media speak inspires.Lead author Dr Ben Marder, of Edinburgh University, tested out the effect of smiley emojis in staff-student communications to seeitincreased commitment and satisfaction.Volunteers were asked their feelings about emails with and without smiley emojis on, from junior and senior staff.The senior lecturer in marketing said they found: ldquoOur students are generation Z, and they are digital natives, growing up in a world of text-ese, emojiis, and this is the normal way of online communication.ldquoThey will become a major part of the workforce soon.ldquoOur findings show that using smileys in general emails, supervision emails and online feedback leads to more positive teacher evaluations and a more favourable responsestudents are invited to undertake a task.ldquoAlthough there is a very small drop in the perceived competence of a staff memberthey use smileys, this is outweighed by the warmth they give off.But it is is best to avoid possible double entendres.ldquoSmileys are the most used emoticon by a long way. We would definitely not use Winkys that would be a mistake. Winkys are a slightly dangerous emoticon to use.ldquoOf course, there are some situations in which emojis would not be suitable, but I think in the vast majority of cases, the use of smileys iscompletely advantageous.Dr Marder added that mixing emojis with normal messages will become more widespread generally.He added: ldquoWe tested it in quite general emails and online feedback, which is a quite formal thing, and my impression is that it is suitable in the vast majority of communication situations.ldquoWhen I use customer service emails from companies quite often they involve an emoji , so people are catching on to it.In the study over  volunteers were shown several e mails without and without smilrey emoticons attached, which came from a senior staff member, a professor, a middle-ranking lecturer, and a junior assistant.Overall the more informal messages with emtoticons had a warmer reception, than others.The study in the journal Studies in Higher Education, suggested: ldquoStaff should consider the appropriate use of emoticons in their communication with students because the positive effects on perceived warmth appear to outweigh the reductions in perceived competence, and the desired behavioural task has a greater chance of being completed.Emoticons came first in the early s when computer scientist Scott Fahlman realised his words were failing him.Finding dficultly in conveying some posts were meant to be taken as a joke, he strung together a colon, a dash and a bracket to make what is now an instantly recognisable character :-.Emojis were never intended for adults, when dreamt up by Shigetaka Kurita, an employee of Japanese telecom company NTT Docomo, in the late s.Kurita was searching for a way to convey messages on the pager system in shorter, more casual prose, but without misunderstanding or offence.He came up with emojirsquos and there are now thousands worldwide.

title: research-sparks-fresh-hope-of-leukaemia-cure
story: It opens the door to developing new drugs for a disease that is notoriously dficultto treat.About  people are diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemiaeach year in Scotland. While younger patients have a better outlook, overall less than one in five patients survive for longer than five years after diagnosis. Survival rates are poor.Now, the protein that fuels it has been identied for the first time. Known as YTHDF, it triggers and sustains the disease.However, it is not needed for healthy cells to , meaning a medication that destroys YTHDF would be a potential cure.AML is a form of cancer that affects blood cells called myeloid cells, which include red blood cells, platelets and certain types of white blood cells. Patients experience uncontrolled growth of immature myeloid cells and do not produce enough healthy blood cells.Older people are most prone. Standard treatment is chemotherapy. If this fails the only hope is a stem cell or bone marrow transplant.The finding, published in Cell Stem Cell, could lead to a medication with signicantly less harmful side effects than existing chemotherapy.The aim would be to efficiently eliminate blood cancer cells in AML ndash without harming healthy ones.Researchers at Edinburgh University and Queen Mary University of London carried out a series of experiments to understand the role of YTHDF in blood cancer.Tests in blood samples donated by leukaemia patients showed the protein is abundant in cancer cells and tests in mice then found the protein is required to initiate and maintain the disease.Further trials enabled scientists to determine the biological pathway by which interfering with theof YTHDF selectively kills blood cancer cells. Importantly, they also showed the protein is not needed to support theof healthy blood stem cells.These are responsible for the production of all normal blood cells. In fact, blood stem cells were even more active in the absence of YTHDF.Professor Donal OrsquoCarroll, of Edinburgh Universityrsquos School of Biological Sciences, who co-led the research, said: ldquoThe study shows the promise of a novel class of drugs as the basis for cancer and regenerative medicine treatments.AML starts in young white blood cells in the bone marrow. It affects about one in  men and one in  women in the UK at some point in their lives.Approximately , new cases occur every year in the US. It is most often diagnosed in older people.Symptoms can include fatigue, fever, frequent infections, bruising or bleeding, weight loss, bone and joint pain, breathlessness, a swollen abdomen and pale skin.The exact cause is unclear but risks include smoking, being overweight, radiation exposure, previous chemotherapy, certain blood disorders and some immune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis.Joint study lead Professor Kamil Kranc, of Barts Cancer Institute, Queen Mary University of London, said: ldquoOur work sets the stage for therapeutic targeting of cancer stem cells in leukaemia while enhancing the regenerative capacity of normal blood stem cells.ldquoWe hope this will establish a new paradigm in cancer treatment.

title: uniform-rules-show-girls-and-boys-need-to-be-taught-respect
story: My early school recollections involve unorm strictures. Girls wore chequered dresses while boys wore trousers and shirt. For a brief time, possibly a cultural thing shed brought with her from home, my mother sent me to school in a heavy kneeskirt, shirt and tie.No one  in my Northern Sydney primary had ever seen a school tie before. Didnt even know they existed. A bit of pleading ensued and soon I had my own chequered dress with its neat white collar and asymmetrical red ribbon at the neck.The light summer dresses came with their own mandatory accoutrements: scungies. Until quite recently Id assumed everyone knew the word scungies. Id no sooner have thought "scungies" unusual than "water" or "bread" but it turns out its the "outwith" of Australia. Its unique to the Aussie dialect.:Conversations about womens vulnerabilities feel so regressiveScungies, for those outwith the know, are giant pants. Hearty knickers, poofy bloomers. Youre basically kitted out in modesty preserving double-undies. Real undies under and big polyester pant protectors over.It was near year-round good weather,you can fathom such a thing, and we were outside all the time, running about, climbing on the playground equipment.I remember exchanges with my young male peers as we clambered up the metal climbing frame. "I can see your pants!" "Thats not my pants, thats my scungies!"Gas on a peep. I mean, it was all the dference of appearing in public in your underwear versus appearing in public in your swimsuit. Its the same bared flesh, but one covering is sociable attire and the other private, despite the two outfits being so similar as to the dference being all but semantics.Thinking back on it only now, werent those great big pants nothing but an early lesson in moulding girls to take steps to avoid the inappropriate impositions of boys. I cant ever once remember anyone calling back "Well, you shouldnt be looking."No. It was incumbent on the girls to cover themselves. If you wanted to run and tumble and sit crossed legged, you must modestly avoid the male gaze, even aged six.:Call for Scottish state schools to be included in child abuse inquiryBut this is decades ago. We tell boys and men to mind their eyes and moderate their actions, of course.Of course not. On Twitter this week I noticed a mother lamenting the fact her daughters school had brought in playsuits for the girls. Not so they could romp around with the same unrestricted freedom as the be-trousered boys. No, because upskirting - little boys looking up girls skirts to see their pants - is increasingly a problem.I read this and my mind went to my scungie days of yore. The boys are causing a problem so lets solve it by covering the girls. We cant tackle the inappropriate behaviour so well remove the temptation by modying the victim.And theres the real problem with this messaging: it says to children, and the children in question here are also six, that girls are a temptation. They are there to be objectied. It says that boys shouldnt be expected to change and that girls are responsible for their behaviour.:Scottish teachers teaching three courses at the same timeThe mother, on social media, said she had challenged the head teacher on this policy and hed sent her a link to playsuits on the MS website by way of reply. What a missed learning opportunity that was.It can take years before women first learn they can and then learn the confidence to stand up to men who want to impose themselves on their spaces, who want to push at their boundaries.Every such opportunity should be taken to point out that, first and foremost, men should change.An AE doctor, Almas Ahmed, has been working since medical school to devise a make up that will withstand an acid attack. She had read about the ordeal of the television presenter Katie Price, who survived a acid attack in  that was orchestrated by her ex-boyfriend, and that  per cent of acid attacks worldwide are against women, and decided to create a "super make up" that would withstand being sprayed with corrosive liquid."People are still trying to destroy womenrsquos lives," Dr Ahmed said. You can only admire her ingenuity and tenacity in developing such a product but you can only despise the social framework that lead to her creating such a product in the first place. Without trust that this abominable problem can be solved, women are pushed to find their own solutions.From Avon and Somerset polices #JogOn campaign encouraging women to run in groups to avoid harassment and assault to the habit of focusing on whether women victims had been drinking, this persistently lingering tendency to focus on the behaviour of women and let men of the hook stunts positive change for all.A "boys will be boys" attitude isnt good enough - for the boys themselves, as well as the girls. Boys can be generous, kind, responsible and respectful, and they should be told that from the earliest possible opportunity.And by parents and teachers, though, not girls. Their lesson is that the only behaviour they are responsible for is their own.

title: herald-diary-tuna-tantrums-and-blowback-for-the-sahara
story: OUR story suggesting that folk in Glasgows west end can sometimes be a tad pretentious brings forth this example from reader Patrick Toal, who tells us: "This was heard verbatim in the Waitrose supermarket in Byres Road ndash a three-year-old or thereabouts recalcitrant kid, brandishing a can of tuna, But Mummy! I emailed him back and said I was very busy working, but would send him something later. He emailed me back saying, Thats hilarious. Send some more."Compose yourselfHERALD arts reporter Phil Miller wrote that a music festival is being planned to highlight the links between acclaimed Norwegian composer Edd Grieg and Scotland ndash Edds great-grandfather was Scottish, although his surname Greig had its spelling altered in Norway. A member of staff gave everyone a Post-it note on which to write what they would like Billy to write. Hoping to get a laugh from Billy, I scribbled: Theres only one King Billy ndash and thats me! However on finding myself actually in the awesome presence of Cesar, despite his totally disarming, friendly demeanour, my courage collapsed. I have it still, a treasured possession, that book bearing Billys signature, and the hallowed inscription, To Charlie, Yo!"What larksMUCH discussion over listeners at Classic FM voting Vaughan Williamss admittedly soporic The Lark Ascending as their favourite piece of classical music. title: mark-smith-what-nicola-sturgeon-said-and-what-it-actually-meant
story: "The devolution settlement in its current form is now seen to be utterly inadequate hellip the status quo is broken."This was the keystone of the speech: the phrase without which the rest of it would fall to pieces. The First Minister talked about having to respond to Brexit, but there are so many s and buts about what leaving the EU will meanso she needs a back-up and its the state of devolution. What this means ndash as Finance Secretary Derek Mackay has already suggested ndash is that the SNP could demand a second referendum evenBrexit is cancelled.:Scottish independence poll: One in five Scots back Nicola Sturgeons Indyref planBut is the status quo broken  Mrs Sturgeon was right to suggest theres a broad view the current set-up is not effective, but as the Lib Dem MSP Mike Rumbles put it in his excellent one-word heckle of the First Minister ndash "federalism!" ndashindependence is not the only solution. A properly federal system could make the UK more responsive to Scottish opinions and, by extension, undermine the case for independence."For the first time in  years, there is a risk of devolution going backwards."A pretty revealing sentence this one and perhaps the moment in the speech where we caught a glimpse of the snarl behind the smile. In advance, the First Ministers spokespeople were briefing about an "inclusive tone" but the warning about devolution doesnt quite fit does it  Mrs Sturgeon has warned before about Tory leaders trampling over Holyrood, but are voters likely to buy talk about devolution going backwards when political history doesnt bear that out  Successive UK Governments have respected ndash and indeed expanded ndash the powers of the Scottish Parliament.:Scottish independence: How European media reacted to Nicola Sturgeons indyref update"The case for independence is even stronger now, given the profound changes in the UK since ."A bit of wishful thinking here from the First Minister. What shes suggesting is that voters witnessing Brexit are starting to think Scotland might be better off out of the UK, but this overlooks the fact that many No voters think that, in the uncertain world of Brexit, independence would pile on more uncertainty. Mrs Sturgeon rightly warned of the UK being side-lined because of Brexit, but shes wrong to think Brexit has necessarily strengthened independence. Five years ago, we had no direct experience of the consequences of leaving an economic union. Now, with Brexit, we do."A choice between Brexit and a future for Scotland as an independent European nation should be offered in the letime of this Parliament."Now were getting to the nitty-gritty. There was a central contradiction in this bit of Mrs Sturgeons speech but it had to be there because of her dferent audiences. On the one hand, she was telling impatient yessers that there should be a referendum in this parliament, but on the other hand, she was telling no voters and dont-knows that a referendum shouldnt happen before we know what Brexit will be like.The problem is that both sides of this contradiction cannot be true. There are only two years left of this parliament, and thats not long enough to establish what Brexit will mean. And another thing: would another referendum in the letime of this parliament give the SNP time to get their facts sorted ndash on the currency for instance  Surely, the SNPs Kenny MacAskill was right with his one-word description of those who expect a second Scottish referendum in the near future: delusional."We will shortly introduce legislation to set the rules for any referendum."Probably the craftiest part of the speech. Mrs Sturgeon knows theres a big part of the Yes movement thats getting impatient with her, but she also knows an attempt to secure a Section  order would be rejected by the British government. Indeed, it already has been ndash less than  hours after the speech, the Prime Ministers right-hand man David Lidington said he thought a Section  was unjustied.Now, the First Minister could have demanded a Section  order anyway and hoped Scots would rise up in fury when it was rejected, but that didnt work out last time did it  So the First Minister came up with another wheeze instead. Rather than getting a Section  and then legislating ndash like  ndash she plans to do it the other way round: legislation then Section .Read more: Nicola Sturgeon planning Indyref before  ballotWill it work though  Perhaps Mrs Sturgeon thinks it will box the UK Government into a corner, but her strategy was only ever about one thing: the impression of momentum without really moving much at all. It was nimble manoeuvring in a tight space. It is a bit of magical misdirection to give the impression, when not very much is happening, that something important is."None of us can fail to be concerned about the polarisation of political debate caused by the Brexit experience."But what about the polarisation caused by the Scottish referendum  Well, indeed, but the First Minister said she wanted to tackle the ision with cross-party talks to explore constitutional change. The question is: what do unionists think theyd get out of it  In the s some thought the Scottish parliament would kill off independence as a political force ndash in fact, it did the opposite and the same could apply to the cross-party talks. It would be more of the same. Another stage of the endless argument. More repetition of the one word thats always tap-tapping on the inside of our skulls: constitution, constitution, constitution.

title: storm-hannah-to-batter-uk-as-temperatures-plunge
story: Gusts of up to mph are forecast to hit the south-west coast by Friday evening.Heavy rain and strong winds throughout Saturday are likely to make conditions feel colder, the Met Office said, as temperatures drop into the low teens, slightly below the average for the time of year.#StormHannah has been named by @MetEireann. The storm will bring severe gales to Ireland on Friday night, with strong winds also expected for southern parts of the UK pic esuddjvNyPmdash Met OfficeApril , Storm Hannah, which was named by Irish forecaster Met Eireann, will bring gusts of up to mph to the south-west coast of Ireland on Friday afternoon, before moving towards Wales and the south west of England.:Temperatures top C on warmest day of the year so farHighs of just C or C will be in stark contrast to the balmy weekend just passed, which saw highs of C recorded in London andthe warmest Easter Monday on record in the UK and Ireland.Met Office meteorologist Greg Dewhurst said: ldquoWhen you add on the strength of the wind and the rain it will feel colder.The Met Office has a yellow weather warning in place for the south west of the country from Friday night until Saturday afternoon.Storm Hannah is expected to clear the UK by Sunday, meaning decent weather for those taking part in the London Marathon, and more settled conditions are forecast tonext week.:Britain basks as Easter heatwave continues#Met Office chief forecaster Frank Saunders said: ldquoWersquore going to see an unsettled period over the next few days, but the forecast for later next week indicates theof high pressure, bringing more settled conditions.ldquoStorm Hannah will move away from the UK during Saturday followed by a transient ridge of high pressure bringing more settled weather to the UK for Sunday, good news for London Marathon runners.

title: glasgow-city-council-should-have-power-to-put-limit-on-orange-parades
story: John Mason, Shettleston SNP MSP, was speaking at First Ministers Questions to highlight the issue of Orange and Loyalist parades in Glasgow following the recent re-routing of a march on Easter Sunday.:Orange Order to march , members past Glasgow church where priest was attackedThe parade was rerouted to avoid a Catholic church where a priest was spat on and a man jailed for the assault, following the decision by the council, it was then cancelled by organisers.Mr Mason believes that the council should have the power to stop parades going ahead altogether however and raised the issue to the First Minister.The parade was then cancelled by the organisers but Mr Mason wants the council to be able to stop parades going ahead in the first place. He askedNicola Sturgeon councilrsquos had enough power over parades.Mr Mason said: "Ithink the council should be allowed to restrict the number of marches by similar organisations to a set number per year.ldquoWe are a democracy and we need to allow marches hat perhaps we donrsquot like unless it is by an organisation that is banned but there can be too many from similar organisations.Posing a question to the First Minister heasked: ldquoI think that the First Minister is aware of the issue of marches in my constituency and, in particular, the recent proposed one by the Apprentice Boys of Derry past a couple of Roman Catholic churches on Easter Sunday.ldquoDoes she think that the current legal arrangements are satisfactory, or does Glasgow City Council need more powers to reduce or restrict such marches The First Minister said that she had confidence in the police dealing with parades.Ms Sturgeon, said: ldquoWe are always happy to talk to councils about the range of powers that are at their disposal. We have faith in Police Scotland to ensure the safety of members of the public and people who participate in marches.ldquoI was absolutely appalledmdashas, I am sure, was everybody in the chambermdashby the incident that took place outside St Alphonsus church last year.:Orange Order in Scotland is on the brink of collapse, according to leading historian Tom DevineldquoThis is an opportunity for all of us to reiterate that nobody should ever be a target for hatred simply because of their faith.A spokesman for Glasgow City Council told the Evening Times: ldquoWe want to ensure the arrangements for dealing with processions work for communities, as well as those who want to exercise their right to march.ldquoThe Leader of the Council recently met with the Cabinet Secretary for Justice to update him on the on-going issues around parades and processions in the city and to seek additional clarity on the legislation ndash particularly in terms of recognising community impact ndash and that dialogue will continue.

title: scottish-independence-scotland-needs-indyref2-to-have-a-choice-to-avoid-brexit
story: The First Minister was speaking on Good Morning Scotland ahead ofthe SNP Spring conference this weekend in Edinburgh.She insisted that the decision to give an update on Scottish independence to MSPs was not timed to appease members of the SNP.:Ian McConnell: SNPs Mackay hits mark on Brexit amid independence poll sound and furySpeaking to the BBC, Nicola Sturgeon said: "The timing is not to do with the SNP conferenceyou think about it, the European Council met when the Scottish Parliament had gone into recess, extended the UKs membership, and I made a statement when the Scottish Parliament came back out of its Easter recess."Had I not done so I guess I would have had opposition parties clamouring to ask why not.:Scottish independence poll: One in five Scots back Nicola Sturgeons Indyref plan"I had given a commitment a long time ago to update the Scottish Parliament as soon as we had any kind of clarity, and whenwe got clarity about a six-month extension thats exactly what I did."I am not suggesting an immediate choice on independence, but I think we now have to start planning for thatthat option is to be there within this term of Parliament."When questioned as why the First Minister didnt bring legislation forward a year ago and why the First Minister had chosen now specically for an update, the First Minister said: "We thought the UK would be out of the EU just now, I accept that the last year or so have not exactly been the most predictable times and Ive been no more able to see what the UK government was likely to do, what a mess it was likely to make of things than anybody  has."We have that six-month window now, the SNP will continue to work with others across the UK to try to find a way out of this Brexit mess for all of the UK."Butthat cant be done, Scotland needs to have a choice. Do we want the damage of Brexit and Brexit is going to do real damage for a long time to come, to our economy, to our society, to our place in the world, or do we want to choose an alternative path as an independent European country."The First Minister also reiterated that she hoped Brexit doesnt happen but she was planning on the basis that the UK was going to leave the European Union and insisted that the timeframe of  was possible.She added: "The last thing I am going to do right now thoughis to narrow Scotlands options. The important thing is over this next period with such fundamental change happening in the UK that is not in Scotlands interests, is that Scotland has maximum options to chart its own way forward."I donrsquot know how @NicolaSturgeon kept her cool with her interviewer on #bbcgms there. Constant interruptions  a stream of misinformation  mistaken propositions. Amateurish  cringeworthy. Time for #BBCGMS to up its gameOn the possibility of a referendum by , the SNP leader said: "Of course its possible. Weve set out on Wednesday that the Scottish Government will now bring forward the framework legislation to put the rules of a referendum on the statute book, we will have that legislation should parliament vote for it, and I believe there is a majority that will do so in parliament."It will be on the statute book by the end of the year, and we will then seek to negotiate with the UK Government the transfer of power that would give the undoubted legitimacy to that referendum."Speaking on a poll that was published today from Survation, Nicola Sturgeon said there was a majority that wanted a referendum and her job was to explain why it would be a mistake to wait too long to carry out a referendum.Addressing comments made by David Lidington who said that the UK would not allow a referendum, the First Minister said that there was a mandate from a landslide Holyrood election and said"this is a Government that cant exactly be described as consistent and is not necessarily going to be in office for very much longer.""Its a government thats very much impossible to have any meaningful negotiation with.":Nicola Sturgeon jokes she would personally dingy President Donald TrumpWhen askeda softer Brexit would delay or cancel a second independence referendum, Nicola Sturgeon said: "If we are taken out of the EU I think peoplein Scotland should have a choice of whether we want that or whether we want to have an alternative path as an independent country."

title: glasgow-university-unveils-50m-waterfront-campus-on-the-clyde
story: The university said the poundmillion development would be located in the historic former shipbuilding community of Govan on the south bank of the river.Professor Sir Anton Muscatelli, the university principal, said the development could make the city synonymous with innovation in the same way it was identied with shipbuilding and heavy industry in the th century.The Clyde Waterfront Innovation Campuswill act as a centre of excellence for a range of new technologies, co-locating industry and world-class research, and will see hundreds of new jobs located in Govan.: Glasgow University given green light to expandThe main developments will include an enhanced James Watt Nanofabrication Centreand a Precision Medicine Living Laboratory.The JWNC will focus on quantum technology and photonics, enabling the co-location of high-quality academic teams with industrial experts in newstate-of-the-art facilities.The Precision Medicine Living Laboratory hopes to strengthen Glasgow and Scotlandrsquos existing position as a world-leader in the field.The project already has financial backing of poundm from the university and pound.m from the Glasgow City Region City Deal. Further investment bids will bring the total to in excess of poundm.The site for the new campus is currently a disused car park at the southern end of the Clyde tunnel, near the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital.A disused car park in Govan where the facility will be builtSir Anton said: "The universitys plans for investment in Govan are an incredibly exciting new chapter for the university and the city and can be as transformational for Govan and the Clyde Waterfront as our move to the West End from the City Centre was in .: Residents told to expect disruption as Glasgow University expandsldquoAs Glasgowrsquos largest university, we are determined to play a full and active part in the public le of our city and our new campus on the south bank of the Clyde will see even more of Glasgowrsquos communities benefit from our activity.ldquoShipbuilding and heavy industry in Govan and on the Clyde waterfront were the pillars of Glasgowrsquos industrial excellence in the th and th centuries."I have no doubt the innovation agenda and industries like quantum technology, nanofabrication and precision medicine can be to the st century Glasgow economy what shipbuilding was in the past."The campus development comes as Glasgow University outgrowsfacilities on Gilmorehill, in the west end.Dr Sara Diegoli, strategic projects manager, said: "It is in a Victorian building so we have some constraints when it comes to expansion."Professor Dame Anna Dominiczak, head of the College of Medicine, added: "Our current clinical innovation zone will be soon full."Bringing industry, NHS and academia together could put Scotland on the map."Susan Aitken, leader of Glasgow City Council, welcomed the development.She said: "The work being done to regenerate Govan and the banks of the Clyde is key to attracting and developing world-class innovation in this part of the city.A map of the site next to the Clyde"It isnt just about those high-tech academic jobs, its about all the other things that come with it."We are building homes, there will be new commercial and retail units, all sorts of new opportunities are being created."There are also plans to establish invention rooms for use by local school pupils.

title: scottish-independence-how-and-when-scotland-could-rejoin-the-eu
story: She included major caveats, not least Brexit going ahead and Westminster approving a section  order.If there was an independence referendum in the next two years, lets say by the end of , andthere was a lsquoyesrsquo vote, how straightforward would it be for an independent Scotland to re-join the EU and how long might it take Read more: Nicola Sturgeon saysScotland needs indyref to have a choice to avoid BrexitThere are many uncertainties here, including whether, when and on what basis Brexit goes ahead, and how long any independence lsquoorcersquo talks would take between the Scottish and UK governments.If the UK stayed in the EU, it would, in many ways, be much easier for an independent Scotland to then stay in or re-join. The UK, including Scotland, would not have erged from EU laws and regulation, and there would not be any of the border problems between Scotland and the rest of the UK that a hard Brexitmight entail.If Brexit does go ahead, then the challenges will be bigger.On independence, Scotland as a European country would be entitled to apply to join the EU. If there was a lsquoyesrsquo vote in December , then orce talks ahead of actual independence might take around two years or more. SoScotland became independent at the start of , how long could it take to re-join the EU This will partly depend on where the Brexit process has got to.If the UK leaves the EU by the end of , the transition period, where the UK stays in the EUrsquos single market and customs union but without a voice or vote, would last until the end of December .This could be extended by mutual UK and EU agreement until the end of . Butthere isnrsquot an extension, or there was a no deal Brexit, then itrsquos possible that to some extent UK laws might have started to erge from EU laws by the time Scotland became independent.Read more:Mark Smith: What Nicola Sturgeon said hellip and what it actually meantBut,there was a lsquoyesrsquo vote as early as December  i.e. by the end of the initial Brexit transition with the UK still fully aligned, that would give scope politically to agree Scotland should stay aligned to EU rules even while the UK subsequently erged.This would require UK agreement but in the face of an independence vote, accepted as legally correct by both sides, itrsquos not obvious why this would be obstructed.AndScotland was clearly aiming to re-join the EU, the EU would also, from the outside, be likely to recommend Scotland did its best to stay aligned.Given UK-EU trade talks would be under way at that point, the UK would also potentially come under some soft pressure from the EU on thisAn independent Scotland would need to apply to join the EU. The European Commission would assess its application and recommend to the European Council whether to agree to open accession talks.Those talks would cover all  chapters of the EUrsquos rules and laws ndash itsacquis. This process,it didnrsquot hit any stumbling blocks, might take two years for the application and talks and then another two years for ratication of the accession treaty .Read more:How European media reacted to Nicola Sturgeons indyref updateOnce the accession treaty was awaiting ratication, Scotland would have observer status in the EU . And it would doubtless in the meantime have an association agreement with the EU, like other accession candidates.SoScotland became independent at the start of , this analysis means it could take until  to re-join the EU.During this  year period, having an association agreement with the EU would be vital. It would set out Scotlandrsquos relationship with the EU in the interim .As long as Scotland had not erged from the EUrsquos rulebook, relatively rapid accession talks could be envisaged. But there will be substantive issues to negotiate, in particular where the UK had special deals and opt-outs.Scotland is unlikely to benefit from the UKrsquos current budget rebate, so its own budget contribution would have to be agreed in the negotiations.Scotland would also be unlikely to get any opt-out from the euro, so it would have to commit to eventually joining the euro . But the currency debate comes to the fore here.Read more:Greens savage SNPs economic plan for independenceIf Scotland had kept the pound sterling, but the UK was outside the EU, then Scotland would not be able to demonstrate that it could commit to join the euro at some indefinite future point.Nor ndashit took up to a decade to adopt its own currency ndash could it show that as a member state it would use its independent monetary policy to target price stability and make its exchange rate a lsquomatter of common concernrsquo with other member states . So this would be a signicant political challenge.Scotland would be likely ndash as both the UK and Ireland currently do ndash to request and probably get an opt-out from the Schengen border-free zone, in order to allow it to remain part of the Common Travel Area that currently exists between the UK and Ireland.But therersquos no obvious reason to expect the EU to replicate the UKrsquos current special opt-in deal for justice and home affairs issues, where the UK gets to lsquopick and mixrsquo which measures it opts into .Read more:Nicola Sturgeon advisers questions point of new Scottish currencyAn independent Scotland could, of course, decide to drop the goal of joining the EU ndash although this would be a major change.It could decide to apply to join the European Economic Areainstead ndash and accept the democratic deficit that Norway contends with, rather than be at the EUrsquos top table alongside Ireland and others.Keeping the pound would then be simpler on that score. But EEA membership might look more problematicthe rest of the UK did end up in a customs union with the EU .EEA members have to be in EFTA ndash and EFTA members have their own trade deals and cannot, without an exemption, be in a customs union with the EU too.Overall, an independent Scotland should have the prospect of a relatively swt and smooth route to re-joining the EU, subject to negotiating the substantive issues covered above.Read more:SNP hit back as Theresa May claims independent Scotland could not stay in EUThe politics of how the EU member states would look at Scotlandrsquos application to re-join would also be much more constructive, not least in the face of Brexit.Accession would still require unanimity, and the future politics of dferent member states, including Spain, cannot be guaranteed. But, for now, the political reluctance expressed in Brussels in  would not be replicated. And Scotland would be able to develop its bilateral relationships with the EUrsquos member states, as its accession talks proceeded.Itrsquos a two-sided dance ndash an independent Scotland would have to decide re-joining the EU was its priority. And the EU would have to agree it could.Dr Kirsty Hughes is director of the Scottish Centre on European Relations. This article first appeared online titled An Independent Scotland in the EU: Timing and Challenges

title: government-steps-in-to-help-save-the-bacon-3m-artworks-export-blocked
story: One of the works is the earliest surviving painting by the renowned artist, who lived from  to .Michael Ellis, the UK arts minister, has placed the export bars on the works, after advice from an expert body.Bacon was one of the most important British artists of the th century.Born in Dublin, Ireland, to British parents, Bacon ranks alongside Turner and Constable in terms of artistic importance, the UK Government said.The four items under an export bar include a painted screen valued at pound. million.It was Baconrsquos first work in triptych, in which a picture or relief is carved on three , attached together and usually presented as an altarpiece.Completed at the beginning of Baconrsquos career around , the screen is thought to be his earliest surviving large-scale work and his earliest surviving figure painting.The other items placed under an export bar are three rugs that were sold separately at auction.Valued at pound,, pound, and pound, respectively, they were hand-knotted at the Royal Wilton Carpet Factory as part of their Wessex range in .Mr Ellis said: "Francis Bacon is one of our most respected and renowned artists, whose works had a huge influence on modern art."It is right that we try to keep these outstanding works in this country, where they could inspire our next generation of world-class artists."He was advised on the matter by the Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art and Objects of Cultural Interest.An independent body, it advises the Secretary of State for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport on whether a cultural object, intended for export, is of national importance.The RCEWA made its recommendation on the grounds of the painted screen and the three rugsrsquo "outstanding aesthetic importance and their value to the study of the works of Francis Bacon, one of the greatest artists of the th century."Richard Calvocoressi, committee member and a former director at the National Galleries of Scotland, said: "Given how much of his work Bacon destroyed, it is crucial that we try to retain these rare early examples in this country."Baconrsquos first short career as an interior designer, principally of modernist furniture and rugs, informed so much of his later painting ndash not least his feeling for space and structure."The decision on the export licence applications for the three rugs and the painted screen will be deferred until  July.

title: concert-review-rufus-wainwright-all-the-poses-tour-glasgow-royal-concert-hall
story: ROYAL CONCERT HALL, THURSDAY, APRIL **** ldquoItrsquos very dficult to keep the line between the past and the present.So goes the opening lyric from Grey Gardens, a Rufus Wainwright deep cut allegedly written on LSD and inspired by a s US proto-reality show. So very Rufus. In the cult series, Jackie Kennedy Onassisrsquo niece and sister are filmed struggling to make ends meet in a dilapidated, cramped apartment shy- sulking at a distance as the First Lady of America amasses inestimable fame and fortune.Itrsquos no coincidence such a queasy public autopsy of familial envy and entitlement appealed to the young Rufus, who was then only a star in his own head. The blazing constellation of the Wainwright musical dynasty simultaneously blinded the teenager with envy and lit the path ahead. Rufus neednrsquot have worried though ndash he would soon go supernova, outshining them all.At Glasgowrsquos Royal Concert Hall on Thursday, this -year-old battle-hardened elder statesman of arch-popera ndash tonight accessorising his advancing years with greying sideburns and moustache - deliberately and provocatively savoured that Grey Gardens line, dragging out its vowels with rolled-eyed irony and a devilish grin. Its clear this introspective, self-aware Canadian fully acknowledges this is the dreaded cash-in tour, a lsquowhole albumrsquo experience so beloved of artists who perhaps have a orce or tax bill looming. Or, simply, have been washed up on the barren shores of middle-aged creative bankruptcy.Itrsquos certainly not dficult to ldquoseparate the past from the present when people are willing to fork out a small fortune to hear tunes you wrote in another letime, perhaps to warm the embers of their own fading youthful fires. Blatant nostalgia requires a positive spin, however - so artists often call such shameless cash-ins anniversary tours, a celebration perhaps, and then confidently order that new : scale Great Pyramid replica for the front room. Everyonersquos a winner.Yet, this is Rufus Wainwright. A true golden child, a prodigious prodigy, a near-as-dammit musical genius revered by his peers and the public with nary an artistic mis-step in his esteemed catalogue. Hence, we can confidently assume therersquos deeper torrents stirring underneath overly-familiar surface waters of lsquothe hitsrsquo. For this is an artist, darling. And even nostalgia can be flipped on its head and reshaped as art, no matter how many layers of bejeweled flamboyance and costume changes eschew the true concept and meaning of the All These Poses tour.Not only did Rufus follow in his lauded parentsrsquo musical footsteps, he utterly eclipsed their cult fame in a blaze of baroque, sullen genius with his early s albums. And we are here tonight, according to the ticket, to celebrate the anniversary of the peerless Poses, released years ago. But, of course, therersquos more to this performance than simply electrocuting old corpses to see which one blinks. Tonightrsquos concert is not just an opportunity for Rufus to remind us why Elton John once called him the greatest songwriter alive. This is clearly also a wake, with the north star of the Wainwright clan taking the conscious decision to sing at the funeral of his youth.Such pretention would be unpalatable without true talent as a scaffold, but tonight we are left in no doubt of Rufusrsquo credentials as a peerless chanteuse. For all his prestigious musical gts, its this artistrsquos inimitable voice that remains his unique selling point ndash a devastatingly precise weapon of mass destruction, melting minds and bodies with depth, richness and audacious verve. A voice powerful enough, perhaps, to soundtrack its ownerrsquos own eulogy. For what transpires tonight is clearly an artist attempting to kill off his past to, perhaps, make way for new inspirations.Make no mistake ndash as le-affirming as Rufusrsquo performing abilities remain - death is the all-encompassing theme tonight. Visually, the thematic intent is obvious, with all the puzzle pieces of presentation coming together to form a cohesively New Orleans masquerade.The tour-tight band ndash each given their chance to shine tonight, particularly Jeff Buckleyrsquos former drummer Matt Johnson - are all dressed solemnly in black. The stark Cha Hotel backdrop projection is scratched out in thick, black impressionistic tears, like a crumbling memory. The ornate Sternberg piano is as black as the space between stars. The lighting is also consciously subdued, often leaving much of the stage in darkness. The Les Paul guitar sitting unloved on a stand has a skull and crossbones strap. Even Rufusrsquo feather boa is black. And, perhaps most tellingly of all, a bespoke coat of feathers which will be theatrically and rather literally employed during the jagged, rf-heavy, baroquely thumping Evil Angel from Poses is black. Undoubtedly, Rufus is telling us something. This is likely the last time his audience will hear these songs for a while.Quickly discarding his eponymous, ambitious yet over-reaching debut album with just eight of its  tracks, a gorgeous cover of Joni Mitchellrsquos Both Sides hints to where Rufusrsquo head is really at. After hiding under the glittery, ornate layers of his debut album, sleepily seducing the adoring crowd with a Leonard Cohen story hersquos told a thousand times, and once again narrating a playful diss at Seal hersquos timed to perfected over the course of this tour, Mitchellrsquos poetry leaves Rufus naked in the spotlight, emoting that wondrous melody with perfect pitch and grace. Ironically, through anotherrsquos writerrsquos words, we get the real Rufus: ldquoBut now its just another show You leave em laughing when you go Andyou care, dont let them know  Dont give yourself away. The lump in my throat remained for the rest of the performance, but many in attendance lost their reserve and wept openly. It was a moment where time seems to stop and all that existed was connection between artist and audience, a fleeting moment of sheer blissful transcendence.Rufus only giveshimself away twice more. Both during the showrsquos second half - a full-bodied, exotically embellished recreation of his undeniable, immortal  masterpiece Poses. The first glimpse of a dent in the armour was the delivery of the crescendo line in Cigarettes and Chocolate Milk: lsquoPlease be kind,Im a messrsquo. Unremarkable words at face value, yet he possessed the line tonight, holding the notes until his breath gave out. Another glimpse of creaking bones under the sparkly top hat, the darkness cloaked by that outrageous rainbow button coat, an ego asphyxiated by his black feather boa.The second moment of transcendence arrivesduring his cover of father Loudounrsquos lsquoOne Man Bandrsquo. On a surface level, itrsquos Rufus playing to the gallery with a knowing wink, living out the drama of his intergenerational dynasty. Yet, its skeletal accompaniment immediately startles, anchored down by The Voice sounding like Marleyrsquos chains ndash ancient regret filling every molecule of the room with hushed awe. "People will know when they see this show  The kind of a guy I am  Theyrsquoll recognize just what I stand for and what I just cant stand Theyrsquoll perceive what I believe in And what I know is true."His lamentful, spat delivery of Loudounrsquos lyric left Glasgow in no doubt - Rufus clearly still harbours deep issues against his father. Yet, this prodigal son is well aware his voice jars with the lyricrsquos emotional honesty, his dadrsquos assured, heartfelt directness withwordshighlighting his own calculated distance as an artist. Itrsquos admirable hersquos willing to reveal his only weaknessis an inability to truly bleed ndash with Rufusrsquo main desire being tosimply put on a show, to impress, bedazzle, leave us in awe at his talents. And he does. Yet, as the years crack hisskin and slowly calcy thebrain, Rufusrsquo theatrical embellishments seem more a prop to pancake over the cracks, powder over the sweat and paint on a smile. Perhaps hersquos throwing these old shapes for the crowd, one last time. All the poses still work for Rufus, of course, yetthis tour truly was a funeral for the past ndash perhaps hersquos finally realizedyou stay the same too long you turn to stone, becoming nothing but a statue of your former self.

title: family fun at aberdeenshire wellbeing festival
story: As part of the Aberdeenshire Wellbeing Festival, Live Le Aberdeenshire will be running free cultural and sports events across the region, with over , opportunities for people to get involved.Highlights include three Best Medicine Comedy Nights in Macduff, Inverurie and Stonehaven in partnership with Breakneck Comedy and the Alcohol and Drugs Partnership, and an animation workshop delivered by Andy Symanowski, director and animator of Aardman Animations’ ‘Shaun the Sheep’ series.Live Le Aberdeenshire, a business unit of Aberdeenshire Council, is also working with Luminate, Scotland’s Older People’s Festival, and CityMoves Dance Agency in Aberdeen, to present Chance to Dance, a whole day of movement workshops for those aged over . Taster sessions in creative writing, painting, pottery and i-Movie making will also be available alongside opportunities such Playlist for Le events for people living with dementia.There are also mindfulness sessions led by guru Martin Stepek, Makaton demonstrations by the NHS speech and language therapists, and ‘Boogie in the Library’.Fire Scotland will be delivering CPR demonstrations in ious libraries with manikins available for participants to practice their le saving skills under the supervision of experts.The Aberdeenshire Wellbeing Festival supports Mental Health Awareness Week which runs from Monday, May  to Sunday, May  and is run through partnership organisations including Live Le Aberdeenshire and NHS Grampian.With  accessible activities for all ages, abilities and interests, across more than  venues, there’s something for everyone.David Cook, Aberdeenshire Culture  Sports Sub-Committee Chair said: “We’re delighted to support the Wellbeing Festival this year, and provide events that are inclusive, welcoming and free to take part in. The team has worked hard to secure national and local funding to boost the range of activities on offer.”Aberdeenshire Council’s Communities Committee Chair Cllr Anne Stirling added: “The promotion of positive health and well-being is a key aim for Live Le Aberdeenshire. It’s great to see such a range of activities that offer plenty of opportunity to spend quality ‘me time’ as well as enjoy fun cultural activities with friends and family.” Look out for the Wellbeing Festival brochure in libraries, and community, health and leisure centres around Aberdeenshire.Full event listings are also available here and at www.liveleaberdeenshire.org.uk and also lists other activities in the Live Le Aberdeenshire Performance and Events Programme.The Aberdeenshire Wellbeing Festival supports Mental Health Awareness Week which runs from  to  May.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The  champion from Kinclune"  Thainstone prepares for annual show and saleviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Vandals strike at Inverurie school viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"
